content:
⚠️ Modified the contribution.
Comment:
Added constraint about [[message]] (there was none before).

✅ Approved the contribution.
Comment: love the idea! good exercise for modulo and ascii conversion.

✅ Approved the contribution.
Comment: Pretty nice puzzle! Maybe reword the alphabet wrapping a bit, but it's a solid puzzle
it's not clear for me what you mean with "wrap around". please show more examples what to do if that character is out ot alpha character..

✅ Approved the contribution.
Comment: Nice clash with the famous Caesar sipher and a little variation with the use of length of words ! Can be done in less than 5 minutes (tested).

This is a very nice variation of the Caesar cipher problem.  I am hesitant about the Reverse version as I think this variation (by word length) might be difficult to derive from the answers alone and still leave time to code the solution. The variation does add some complexity which takes a bit of additional time to code.  The statement is clear and the test cases are solid, covering all the bases.  

* Remove Reverse and I will approve this Clash.

Nice clash! From trying it in IDE I got the following questions:
- In your description you only use uppercase, and indeed I found out all is with uppercase - but it is nowhere actually mentioned. You can include in the description (maybe in constraint section) that only uppercase is used.
- At no place is actually mentioned that encode means shifting forward. It follows from your example, but during the clash I started wondering, because both DECODE and ENCODE are required, so technically your example could be for DECODE or ENCODE as well. In my opinion, this would already be solved if you change 'For example, the message CLASH OF CODE becomes...' into 'For example, ENCODING the message CLASH OF CODE results in ...'
No idea what does encode / decode shift, shifting up or down.

Hi ndevfr
I really like this challenge. I can already sense the satisfaction I will feel when finding the patter in reverse. It will be excellent.

I think that in stead of using the wording 'go back to  "A" if we need to go beyond "Z".' maybe you should use the wording "if we need to go beyond "Z" we wrap around to "A"'. I think it will be clearer as you don't need to stop and think if the "go back" is important when reading quickly.

 For reverse it might be good with a test case for ABACUS. Your first thought will be Caesar cipher and I think FGFIAY will help since you see the two As both become F and B becomes G. It is easy to see that both are 6 steps up. Then you have an easy check with C.

Make the C in Cipher in Goal lower case.

Two suggestions for ease of reading when doing "Fastest", I found the info in description, but only after failing test cases.
- More explicit mention of direction in which letters are shifted. I misread that they shift to the left because of "For each letter, we will go back..." and we'll read it yet quicker in the actual "Fastest" clash.
- Better to add in Constraints section that words consist only of "english capital letters", it took me a while to find it in the description of input. Wondered if small letters were after capitals as in ASCII or if we were supposed to convert input to upper case. Had to guess that there is no ".!?" marks.

11 minutes is what it did take me to solve it, because I've read description too inattentively first. The puzzle is good for Clash. I am curious how long it takes for others.

The historical reference is wrong. Julius Caesar did use a code based on shifting the letters in a message by a fixed number (+3).  The progressive version/variation of the encoding was not on his table.
Please correct the historical reference to: 'a word-by-word progressive variant of the Caesar Cipher'
Otherwise a nice challenge - maybe better for a puzzle than for CoC. 
remember that any fair  programmer should have a chance to solve in ~5 min. Might not work with 'reverse'.

Goal section
* Suggest to change "as many ranks as the word contains" to "as many ranks as the number of characters that the word contains".

* Suggest to add a new line above "For example" and below "each letter of CLASH".

* Suggest to format DECODE and ENCODE as {{constants}} instead of in <<bold>>.

* Please mention that the shifting of ranks operates on a wrap-around basis, i.e. we will go back to "A" if we need to go beyond "Z".

Input section
* Suggest to format DECODE and ENCODE as {{constants}} instead of in <<bold>>.

* Suggest to change the variable name "input" to some other word because "input" is a keyword in Python.

Stub generator
* Suggest to change the variable name "input" to some other word because "input" is a keyword in Python.

Game modes
* It seems a bit difficult to guess the requirement in Reverse mode. Just my opinion.

Thanks.

Hello,
Thank you for your message.
I have updated my proposal taking into account all your advice.
For the "Reverse" game mode, I thought it was nice to think about the coding (I tried to choose cases using words of different lengths) but if the community finds it too difficult, I will indeed remove it. I can also add other cases that might help.

Hello,
I have updated this reference.
Thank's a lot !

Hello,
I have made the modifications.
